One thing I noticed that Marvel did (and was bothered by) was their over reliance on comedy.  The Phase 1 movies had a bit of humor thrown in, and people praised it due to the comparison with DC (and other superhero movies) that were focusing so much on "gritty" storylines so the comedy added much needed levity to the genre.  But, as the phases progressed, they kept pushing the comedy more and more, to the point where now it's almost just as bad as the gritty DC storytelling. This seemed to be the culmination of that, with Taika almost thinking "people really loved the funny and goofy aspects of marvel, so let's go all in!"
For someone called Critical Drinker you sure lacked critical thinking when making this video, pal. Because your critical analysis completely failed when you decided to oppose Ragnaschlock and Dumb and Thunder against each other like one is better and the other isn't. They're both bad. The scenes you're comparing are both godawful, but for different reasons. If anything, the one from Ragnaschlock is marginally worse because the theater play from Dumb and Thunder is merely bad out of subjective and technical reasons, but hardly is a detriment to the characters or story. Meanwhile, the theater play from Ragnaschlock completely character assassinates Loki and the lore of Asgard. Why is  Loki so careless when impersonating Odin when previously he was known as cunning and smart and his schemes would never appear on the surface. And was he never thinking about Thor returning back to Asgard and suspecting something? Did he never think about what to do in that situation? Not a great plan. And from that point on it's character assassination galore, for both Thor and Loki. You can hate that scene in Dumb and Thunder, but pretending the one from Ragnschlock is good is critically incorrect. I still can't believe there are people in Mauler's circles who like that movie, considering it's worse in terms of character assassinations, lore destruction and horrendous plot and dialogue writing than even the worst of Disney Star Wars.
The biggest threat to a franchise is their own success.  When a show or movie does well in a franchise, it gives off the perception that the IP is good or that the director is good or the actors are good or any other superficial thing. And this results in studios loosening up their wallets to invest more in the sequels. However, this is the main reason why these sequels fail.   More money =/= better quality.   When you have a production that involves some level of hardship, this actually helps to ensure the final product is the best that it can be. However, by removing those hardships, you remove the incentives to make something good. It's something that I like to call "First Draft Syndrome." Normally, when you write a draft of what you want to do but find that it runs into issues with other creatives or perhaps budget issues, then you're forced to refine it and re-think the design. This process of refining the draft makes it better. And the more it gets refined, the better the final draft ends up being.  However, if you remove the roadblocks and let people just take the first draft and run with it, then you've effectively removed any incentive to refine the draft to make it better or more concise. You're just using the first draft without so much as a second look. First draft syndrome.
Melissa Hackarthy needs to go take a piss

Taika Waititi is like a guy who has successfully built and designed houses. With Thor: Ragnarok, he was given the opportunity to oversee the construction of a well-designed skyscraper.  After rising to the challenge (pun intended), he met with his bosses who inexplicably announced, "Now we're going to let YOU design a skyscraper." Instead of admitting that he had no idea how to do that, Taika just started laughing his ass off and stacking a bunch of shiny and expensive materials as high as he could with no rhyme or reason.  At the ribbon-cutting ceremony for what had essentially become a skyscraper-sized pile of garbage, the public openly expressed its disapproval of the misguided and self-indulgent monstrosity which now marred the city skyline.  Learning nothing from the abysmal failure, Taika's bosses have allegedly rehired him to design a second skyscraper, this time in the Star Wars district.  Not surprisingly, citizens are fleeing the city in droves.

Really, this is a good lesson for anyone making any sort of published media period. If you're going to tell a story, you need to know the purpose of each scene, what it accomplishes, and how effectively it accomplishes it. If your first response to being asked if your scene accomplishes one of those three things is, "Well, that's too strict of a criteria," you aren't making something for others to enjoy, you're making something purely for yourself. And yes, I've talked to many an aspiring writer, and when I ask if their scene either develops a character or progresses the plot, they gave push back to that.
I think I've learned more about story writing in the past 11 minutes than any writing class has managed, lol.

Pretty bad when a director can‚Äôt even map out the landscape for the people working on the project. His job is literally to do the set up to make post productions‚Äô life easier. You said that he needs level headed people around him. No the director need to be the one who is the level headed navigator the one who guides the team to the destination, it‚Äôs their job to lead not be babysat by the rest of the crew. I haven‚Äôt worked on anything big budget but I was the producer of two student films and getting a good director was crucial to the workload and synergy of the team. It‚Äôs all about clarity, those that didn‚Äôt consider clarity or make styles guides and story notes confused the production team rather then giving then drive and you know direction. A director is quite literally just a film GPS.

I do have to contest drinker on one part with the scene in love and thunder. Yeah it was a bad scene and he has a LOT of good points on that.  The scene DOES however serve to provide subtle world building. The real problem with the scene is that it got front and center attention. This is the kind of scene that you put in the background and it gets like 10-15 seconds of spotlight... the closer to a minute it gets the worst the scene becomes.   For those reading this in the future, imagine that same scene except the screenplay is in the background as the tourist guide goes over the hammer and vague (inaccurate/ hyperbolic) descriptions of the Asgardian history and culture, meanwhile an actual Asgardian or two looks on with disgust the more this person talks. As they go over the hammer and talk about the events of Ragnarok, the screen pans over the one of the asgardians looking down in shame and melancholy before the screenplay in the back makes a big sound and they look over where the camera focuses and the poor retelling is continuing. The scene lasts only a few seconds, half a minute tops. Focus back to the tourist group as the continue, leaving one lone hoodie wearing person to look back at the glass dome with Mjolnir in it. Person approaches glass and reaches a hand to touch it longingly, yet weakly. Rotate camera to show a sickly looking Jane Foster (suffering from chemo treatments; gaunt cheeks, pale skin, dark circles under the eyes). She stares into the glass, seeing a healthy looking reflection of herself and shards of Mjolnir simultaneously (to represent how her life is shattered and broken as well as setting up foreshadow) and while staring flashback to scenes from what happened after Dark World and before Infinity War when she was snapped and images with voice overs of her cancer diagnosis. In my opinion, a much more powerful version of the scene right there with about the same amount of time and saves a lot of discussion later as well.   Additionally, she REALLY needed to be initially clumsy with her powers. She could have been a much faster learner than Thor on how to control the power and perhaps a LOT more innovating than him on how to use the thunder/lightning. This would further drive the nail that Thor is brutish yet powerful and Jane is clever and innovative. It also would have been super helpful to reestablish their romantic feelings for each other... since they already claimed it was killed when Portperson said she wasn't going to come back and they killed off the romance. It also would have been a good moment to actually let the audience see them connect as Thor would have a logical reason to care and like her outside of the idea that the plot needs him to. He would be able to be attracted to her warrior spirit and she would be able to understand more of Thor's view of things. During the teachings, he could have been able to slide in how he felt about her leaving him and she could have given her perspective on the events and why she left him. It can ALSO create tension as they can argue over what is right since they both have experience with the powers of Thor while coming from completely different views and upbringings.   Drinker is right that it is a poor scene, but it isn't entirely pointless. It just could have been MUCH better written and directed.

Its SUCH a terrible piece of garbage-movie.
You know why Batman movies are so well received? They don't focus on Batman.  The Problem with the MCU-heroes is, that we know them. Character development is limited, what we can have is side-character development or relationship development, or we put life-changing events in every movie. But that'll grow old very fast.  Butman does this differently. We all know Batman. We know his type of personality, we know his history, we know his relationships. Literally nothing about Batman is unknown. They sneak in some variety but at his core Batman always remains Batman.  So, with that literally out of the window, how is it possible that there are good Batman-Movies? His enemies. Look at the Dark Knight trilogy for example. It has its main focus set on the Villains. And it's not just the story telling that is set around the villains, even the perspective we have as audience during fight scenes is usually the perspective of the villains and / or henchmen.  And that is why Batman works. Becuase his enemies are much more interesting than he is. And you can have a new enemy each movie AND you can have the villains have character development on a much slower pace. You can re-introduce villains later and have them develop a relationship with the main hero. This also works well for Batman, as he is a hero based "in the shadows". A Superman movie, for example, that would be like that would be terrifying. While you want Batman to be terrifying, Superman isn't supposed to be that.  So how to apply this to the MCU? Literally the same. They should keep up with introduction series & movies for heroes which have their focus set on the hero/group that is being introduced. It's literally the backstory told as its own movie, so to speak. But from there slowly transition to a "villain" focused story-telling, with focus on the hero when it makes sense.  -  Another point to make is, that the MCU grows closer to its source material. And the source material, is not the most serious one. And that's where the MCU-clientele breaks apart, because the comics are made for children originally. And a lot of us joined this hero-universe based from comics as adults. So, having the impression that it is silly is kinda normal for those of us. There's still the point to make that for those who grew up and adore these comics this is still too far away or too hard trying to "overwrite". There are many reasons not to like or like something.  I just don't think it is the end of the world to no longer like the MCU content. Move on to different things. It's not just that the MCU developes and changes, you do too. And since it has been more than 10 years since this all startet, you, dear reader and MCU-watcher, are not the same person that started watching MCU movies.
Thor Ragnorok was one of my favorite movies for quite a while when I was younger , I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre not as critical of it as you are of other marvel movies.

I think the BIGGEST issue with Love and Thunder and the Asgardians now living on earth, is the people themselves, more specifically their attitude toward Thor and the Asgardians as a whole. I get that normal people at this point in the MCU have obviously gotten use to super powered humans, Villains, Monsters, Evil AI Robots and even Aliens. BUT, Super humans, monsters and aliens are just different types of people and other kinds of life, even Captain marvel herself with her near limitless powers is STILL just a normal mortal HUMAN woman at the end of the day. Thor and the other Asgardians on the other hand are a TOTALLY DIFFERENT story. The Asgardians are LITERAL FUCKING GODS, they are IMMORTALS who have been around for untold centuries and are in control of and created Valhalla, the very place where people's literal souls can go to after death and PROVES beyond a shadow of a doubt that there IS LIFE AFTER DEATH. And yet all the regular people are just acting as if its just another day at the park and treating them as if they are just normal people or like any other group of "refugees". The simple fact that Thor, Odin and the others even EXIST completely DISPROVES Christianity and all other Monotheistic religions on earth in their entirety. They provide people with direct access to actual gods and information on the afterlife and yet they dont even bat an eye at this. That to me that is the most UNREALISTIC thing in the entire MCU, people would NOT be just sitting there watching a play. Thor and the other Asgardians would be bombarded by mobs of people with a million questions and would be treated and even worshipped as Gods by people of every walk of life. Not to mention the governments of the world wanting access to the Gods. Sure Thor might not be bothered by them, but do you think for a second that governments wouldn't try and get access to a Valkyr or other Asgardians? If i had been in charge of this movie and even Ragnarok, i would have the Asgardians have to essentially hide out somewhere secluded in Norway in order to avoid contact with people because of their reaction to literal gods coming to earth. The way they portray New Asgard as a JOKE, as if its a new "Disney land" with rides and all this other GARBAGE just makes the entire movie feel silly when there needs to at least SOME sense of urgency and tension to all the Norse gods being homeless and forced to live on earth. They just treat the Asgardians as if they are some sort of freak side show attraction rather than Gods.
Okay okay, I saw this movie with my dad, and he's this old stoic, deep voiced, serious guy and I thought he was gonna hate it but it's tradition that we see superhero movies together. He ended up laughing at all of the dumb jokes so hard, and I couldn't not find it infectious. Now that I've moved out and becoming an adult, I don't get to do a lot of stuff with my dad anymore so it was a nice way to cap off a weekend at home during the summer. I know it's flawed heavily, but this movie is now attached to a really heartwarming, nostalgic part of my brain. Sorry guys, it's bad, but I love it

It could have been pulled off if it was a dream sequence, or a poor retelling of what actually happened by an over-enthusiastic character.  After the scene ends, you have a scene with two characters - the over-enthusiastic storyteller, and a non-believing listener.  "There's no way that happened" - "no, I swear it really happened that way", etc.  The scene would have had its entertainment value, but the sense of relief I would have felt knowing it was just a fantasy would have been immense. It's strange though, what you said about buying into his own hype that gave me a flashback to a movie I saw some years ago, some quaint weird surrealist drama where the protagonist was some kind of artist. A talent agent says to him "I don't want you catching what he's got", "What's that" the protag replies, "Success".  Wierdly insightful (especially for the late 00s); given how many directors and artists have fallen into mediocrity or mindless self-indulgence. Look at Stephen Moffat - sure Dr Who isn't the MCU - but it was depressing to see him go from writing some of the best Nu-Who episodes before (and after) becoming showrunner to writing Peter Capaldi as a high school teacher as if he were Great Teacher Onizuka.  My best mate, a far superior writer than I, suggested: Well, sometimes people only really are capable of producing good content when they have that drive to succeed and prove themselves; and other times, people just run out of ideas. That would fit, as it seems in cinema, the MCU is the place creativity goes to die.

I'm gonna go ahead and say that all of the Thor movies, including Ragnarok, are bad. The first one breezed through plot points at breakneck speed and needed to be at least a couple of hours longer, the second was too serious and lore-heavy, the third isn't even remotely serious enough and (like a broken clock) got only two things right in the form of the 80's-flavored setting and the soundtrack, and the fourth is just an overexaggerated and even more flawed redux of the third. Nobody has literally any idea what to do with MCU Thor, and it shows. Worse, Thor has gone through so many directors who each have a different vision for him that I defy anybody to define him as a character. Each iteration of him differs wildly from the others, but they're all supposed to be the same man. Thor and his movies are all gigantic messes. Thor deserves better.

I found the elevator scene in Thor: Ragnarok an example of a Taika scene done well. The development between Thor and Loki really hits an all time high in the brief dialogue they have in the elevator to the hangar. Thor acknowledges his brother, Loki for who he is and not what Thor hopes/wants him to be, but expresses his unconditional love for his brother regardless. The scene ends with Thor actually putting that new character development immediately into action by planting the shock device on Loki. Thor knew that after expressing his love to his brother that Loki would likely try something cheeky, showing further that he won't be tricked so easily as in the past.   This scene has 2 jokes. One after a long, digestible pause in the elevator to break the cathartic moment with their "Get help" bit. This bit shows that sense of brotherly love their relationship has desperately needed and I think fits well since they give the dialogue some time to breath before whipping it out. The other, when Thor actually gets the best of Loki ( and some payback) by unexpectedly planting that shock device on him. Both of these jokes were funny (imo) and actually expressed the recent growth Thor has gone through as a character.   Love and Thunder takes the goofyness from those jokes but removes the substance that respects the characters and story being told. They could have easily pulled this off with characters such as Gorr (if they had put decent time into his backstory) and Jane Foster who had a lot of potential for character growth. *sigh* I guess not :/

What I imagine is that the play elaborates on what Hela did to Thor's hammer. They could show how Hela secretly collected the hammer before being teleported to Asgard. Tbh, to me, this movie ran like a poorly written fanfiction made by an 8 year old. It was all over the place and the whiplash of a sad moment suddenly getting hit with jokes was abysmal.  There are several ways I feel like this could've been written INFINITELY better. One of them being just a casual (not so casual) adventure with the Guardians.  I am incredibly salty they didn't give us a found family dynamic between Thor and the Guardians and I will continue to be salty.  The content for writing their dynamics would be a GOLD MINE. The group and Thor all care about each other because they've all been kind of in the same place because of mostly the same person (Thanos).  Drax lost his family like Thor did with his brother, to Thanos or one of Thanos' lackeys. Quill and Nebula lost Gamora to Thanos. Think of Thor interacting with Nebula, Thanos' daughter. The tension, or the unresolved trauma of watching half of Asgard and then half the world die, because of Nebula's father.  Thor could've resolved whatever bit of trauma he had remaining in Endgame, through Nebula.  And while working through trauma and problems, they try to save people from Gorr.  And at the end of the movie, Thor ends up leaving the Guardians anyways because of several reasons, like him not feeling like he really belongs in a group like that right now and reminiscing on older times with the other Avengers and thinking how he could never really replace them even if he tried. But also because he has a duty to uphold now, which is to take care of Gorr's kid.  The Guardians say goodbye to Thor and make heartfelt promises to each other to visit every now and then for dinner or adventures.  Would've been really nice tbh.  Also, formatting is weird sorry. The next commenter may be the opposite.  Love and Thunder on the other hand.... feels like it was out of control... There were puns that needed moderation badly. The tone was unfortunate. I can appreciate the humor but i barely watched any previews so was pretty disappointed to find out the Guardians were essentially a cameo. Had no idea about the god butcher but when i saw the segment where he was introduced i was excited thinking they dropped the Guardians so they could do a serious tone Thor movie again with some light humor sprinkled within("ANOTHER" smashes coffee cup).   Instead we had a movie with a cameo from Zeus. A Cameo from Gorr(bit more then a cameo to be fair). A cameo from the Guardians. A Cameo from Sif(Marvel or whoever owns this franchise please stop treating the character this way she deserves better).  Thor's screaming goats (while vaguely lore accurate) got more screen time(and too much scream time) then half the cast.   The weapon romance subplot(there's a rare sentence if i ever heard it) was positively silly. sillier though was the tremendous drop in power Stormbreaker showed versus Mjolnir(no doubt intentional to make Mjolnir Shine a bit more). Made worse that the great plan when confronted by the idea that Gorr was after the Axe was to throw it out into space. You know what else could channel the Bifrost? Gungnir(Also Hofuo) one of those might've been destroyed when Asgard blew up but the location the Asgardian ship exploded is probably public knowledge by now(distress signal). If i wanted a relic capable of channeling the Bifrost even if i wanted to kill gods I'd probably go for the unguarded relic in space over the one that went toe to toe with a complete infinity gauntlet AND WON! Stormbreaker passing a few mooks turned them into liquid(or ash) and the one holding it almost won a one on one fist fight with the HULK!(results arguable)  I'll skip talking about Zeus because that scene was pretty funny(if disrespectful but it worked so i won't complain). What was odd to me was that they acquired thunderbolt before losing Stormbreaker (valk uses it briefly but literally has it taken out of her hands to and used against her which is a travesty for someone who went toe to toe with Hela and survived[though to be fair SO DOES THOR]). Then after arriving they decide to throw away Stormbreaker instead of using it to escape. This is weird to me because both weapons could be used to teleport long distances and instead they ride on a boat pulled by the screaming goats. This does leave the mighty thor behind as long as you ignore the part where thor teleported three people across the realms almost immediately after(ish) acquiring it. then after becoming familiar with it this skill gets... harder?  Then we reach the end of the movie... So... Thor could've buffed up a mass crowd of people at anytime? Feel like there was a pile of dead Asgardian parents who might've been able to make some use out of that when being attacked earlier in the movie. You might argue that it was Thunderbolts power. But i believe it was "the power of THOR!"  And then there was the end... great job you won... oh wait nevermind... They missed a golden opportunity to do something special and set the stage and stakes INSANELY high(again). But what is love?

Some of you ( a lot of you, actually ) seem to be forgetting these are based off comic books . And like that medium, these movies have different artists and teams creating unique runs. So, you pass on picking up the latest issue of Thor:  Love and Thunder.  Personally I loved the film, I love Taika and what he brings to the table, and you don't. Cool man. If that doesn't remind you of arguing over the merits and flaws of particular runs and titles in front of the comic racks at your local shop, then I feel oddly sad that you missed out on doing that.   I also love the absolute bonkers style of the new show She-Hulk. It's absurd, it's cheesy, it's in your face with it's messaging, it's saturated and feels like a sugar coated brick to the face. It's just fun. And I feel that Love and Thunder brings that same kinda wack-a-do energy to otherwise extremely bleak subject matter. I don't want to take the opening sequence and ride that energy the whole film.  If that's your cuppa, I strongly recommend the animated masterpiece Grave of the Fireflies. Nobody ever talks about how AI is probably generating these movies now.  Not a joke and can easily be proven.  Only question is how much.  From the very first movie ever made it was never 100% authentic due to acting, staging, cutting etc etc but let's say at the start it was 99% authentic.  Then along comes CGI which we already know existed like 30 + years ago.  So now we are at nearly 50% artificial.  What if now it's just a human putting in some parameters into a movie generator, and then a human edits the AI generated movie or 90 to 99% artificial.

But I would suppose if it was the other way around there might be a bit of an uproar if for example a Norwegian was to write and direct a movie about Hawaiian folklore. Of course since as far as I know there's not recently been any good points for comparison but my double standards sense is tingling.

Marvel Studios Thor: Love and Thunder is a very fun watch just so long as you don't take it too seriously.  If you took out all the comical parts then the movie would be about half as long.  The film is a comedy and it is pretty clear that Chris Hemsworth loves hamming it up in a big way.  His character Thor was always a bit comical, which offends some people because they look at Thor as a classical hero.  However, the other half of the movie makes for a pretty good Marvel adventure, and the combination of comedy and adventure is great just so long as you are not put off by that kind of thing.  Christian Bale deserves much credit for his portrayal of the villain Gorr, who is on a personal mission to destroy the "gods".  You need a good villain to make a good superhero movie.  Although Gorr is not as deep of a character as Thanos, and at times might seem a bit superficial, Christian Bale pours his heart into the role.  He gets the job done.

With Halloween a month away, if you've not already decided on a suitable film to review, may I humbly submit for consideration Jacques Tourneur's 1957 masterpiece 'Night of the Demon' (a.k.a. Curse of the Demon across the pond). Not a single wasted line or scene in the entire movie, brilliantly cast, acted, lit, scored and directed. Hell, even the SFX aren't bad for the time. He was fine as a side character with a few minutes of screen time total, but he quickly gets annoying as a main character  - Thor becoming a dad like Tony  - Thor needing to ‚Äúfigure out who he is‚Äù for like the third time now - Getting the thunderbolt because it‚Äôs a powerful weapon that can help stop Gorr like when Thor went to make Stormbreaker in IW   Also, all the characters felt like parodies of themselves. Pretty much the entire movie felt like if the Team Thor shorts were turned into a theatrical movie. Nothing but jokes, turning Thor into an idiot, etc.  Also, Taika really seems to hate Sif and the Warriors Three. He killed off the three instantly with no regard for Thor‚Äôs emotional response, he brought Sif back in a comic accurate costume just to cut off her arm and write her out of the movie, and I feel like it was all just to make room for Valkyrie and Korg (which is just an excuse for him to talk more and more in these movies). I‚Äôm pretty sure the only reason Sif wasn‚Äôt killed in Ragnarok was because of scheduling conflicts with the actor.  And so much of the dialogue was basically just exposition and describing the plot like they‚Äôre reading script notes or something. It‚Äôs that one line Korg had in Ragnarok where he analyzed the loss of Mjolnir and applied to basically everyone.    To me, Thor‚Äôs arc should have ended with him becoming king. It‚Äôs what his entire journey was leading up to, so to basically have that thrown away in favour of more wacky adventures feels like a character assassination.

Gotta disagree a bit on the definition of scene or rather what it should accomplish. Most screenwriters would posit that a scene MUST advance the plot first  then character build or worldbuild, any scene worth having in a movie should be able to at least advance the plot and be able to do one of those things and advance the plot if it dies do one of those thing. World building can be done through environmental storytelling and character building should be done based on their reactions to the plot.

Taika directs mostly adaptations. The problem is, he's an amazing director when he can deviate and go with his own concepts, but sucks when he has to stick to the original material of whatever he's  adapting. Let's compare the two things he's most known for rn: Jojo Rabbit and Thor LaT.  For Jojo Rabbit he took a grim, confusing (and kinda plain in it's execution) story, stripped it to it's bones and built a cute, heart warming story around the same concept. Great movie, we all love it. But for things like Thor, he has to stick maybe not to the original material per se, since the MCU it's not very faithful to the comics, but he has to follow some guidelines that make all these blockbusters work as complimentary works of one another, or at least make them feel like they're all taking place in the same universe. Specially when talking about sequels, since they continue the story of characters we already know and have grown attached to. And Thor we've seen for seven whole-ass movies and through ELEVEN years. Even with each director having their own opinions or ideas of how (of *what*) Thor should be, he has been pretty consistent through these eleven years (yes, even fat Thor in Endgame). But here, Taika just turned him into an immature manchild. Taika was more interested in making a comedy movie than in making a Thor movie, which did not work for the character and was unfair to all the development he's gone through.  That's also why I think his Star Wars movie will suck. Star Wars has a very specific energy around it that requires you to watch the 6 original movies AND understand them in order to make a successful Star Wars product. Disney has been hit or miss with this. We've got great pieces of media that succeed at giving us that 'Star Wars' feeling while being whole new stories like Andor, Rogue One or The Mandalorian and then we have products like the sequels or the rest of Disney+ original series that not only betray the concept of Star Wars, but (in case of the sequels) also sh*t on it.  And with Taika admitting he hasn't watched the source material, and how he has handled characters that needed to be more than comedy, I'm really worried about how his SW film will turn out.

I can think of a Movie scene that one, continues the plot, gives charechters development, and world builds all at the same time. You Remember Star Wars: The Empire Strikes back, Where vader tells Luke he is his father. Well not only does it develop a new story, but alsk makes you question, why did Ben Lie to luke, is Vader telling the Truth, Is Vader really Anakin, What happened to cause this? It not only contined the story, but allowed 3 new sideplots to be introduced. It also world build because it causes events like the Clone wars to be made, and gives Star Wars and the Galactic Empire more of A tragic story, about the fall of the jedi order, by the hands of one man. Thats why that scene was perfect, because it wasnt only made to shock people, it was designed to deepen the plot, create new problems and stories, and give Luke and Vader some much needed Development. Now every Marvel Movie makes a scene to make you scream in the theaters, but has no purpose. Why did the illuminati show up in multiverse of madness, if there just going to be killed off? So disney can get fans hyped, so they go watch the next subpar superhero movie they push out. The illuminati did nothing to expand the plot, they were there for the sake of fan service, and it makes Marvel Movie unrealistic recently.

The 4 Batman movies from the 90s and the 4 Thor movies from the MCU have a lot in common   The 1st movie (Batman / Thor) was a good introduction to the hero with one of the best movie villains of all time. And the villain falls to his death at the end. And the hero faces off the main threat with no suit who presumably dies to show even without the suit and weapon he is worthy.   The 2nd movie (Batman Returns / Thor The Dark World) had a much more dark tone with a love story that doesn't work out in the end, and you think the anti villain working with the hero dies but revealed that they survived as the credits role.   The 3rd movie (Batman Forever / Thor Ragnarok) gets a different director and makes the franchise more colorful and comedic, and has a villain that wears green and another with a burned face. And also teams up with someone that is green. Also the death of a father that motivates them to fight.   The 4th movie (Batman and Robin / Thor Love And Thunder) has the same director as the 3rd and takes that comedic tone to another level that it makes the entire movie look like a Saturday morning cartoon and the outfits look more like toys rather than armor. Plus has a female version who suddenly gets the same powers with no training, but able to fight with the suit on. And at the end they run towards the screen as the credits roll.

I underwent the Highland Abilities Battery as part of a career process. It put me on the 50th percentile for creativity. I was a little miffed at this, thinking myself quite a creative chap. My consultant told me that, in her experience, and in the aggregated data of 100s of 1000s of other tests, 50% was a bit of a sweet spot in that creativity also requires objectivity and reflection. People on the 90th percentile get idea after idea after idea and find it hard to embed them or make them coherent. This might have just been patter to ensure I wrote a good review for the consultant, but in actual fact, I think she was right. I think Critical Drinker gives us a prime example in his analysis of the director of this film. Anyway, that‚Äôs all I‚Äôve got time for‚Ä¶

The issues behind *Thor: Love and Thunder* as a film remind me of similar issues with George Lucas. When he made the original *Star Wars* trilogy, he was the ideas guy, but he still had others pushing back, and making it with him.  When it came to the prequels, he was such a big name, he basically had carte blanche to film whatever he wanted.  While I'd argue that the *Star Wars* prequels ARE better films than *Thor: Love and Thunder,* they also had similar issues with not enough people pushing back on what George Lucas wanted.

Many strong points, though I feel that you (like most people) give Ragnarok (while it was still better than Love & Thunder) too much credit.   The character insight Ragnarok's theatre scene provided was, I felt, significantly too heavy-handed and actually somewhat contradictory to established characterization; Loki is supposed to be a narcissist and a glory hound, but a crafty-and-calculating rather than cartoonishly-over-the-top-and-stupid one. At the end of Thor: The Dark World, he addressed Thor with a pitch-perfect impression of Odin (I understand the scene was actually originally written to *be* simply a conversation between Odin and Thor, with the twist that it was really Loki added later while keeping the dialogue intact) -- meanwhile, his Odin impersonation in Ragnarok is downright pitiful (I could do a better one easily) and falls apart in moments.   This is one of numerous examples of Ragnarok taking plot threads and characterizations from the previous films and flippantly tossing them into the waste bin, reducing what-should-be serious story elements to cheap punchlines, etc. I felt that most of the major criticisms now coming at Love & Thunder from many quarters were also applicable to Ragnarok, if perhaps to a somewhat lesser extent.
There is a small amount of fantastically great movie writing, there is plenty of good movie writing, lots of average or mediocre movie writing, there is a ton of absolutely terrible stuff that got stuck to the bottom of your shoe that smells really badly movie writing....and then there's this movie's  infected weeping sore that passes for "writing".

This is a scene you definitely want to include if you have a side hustle with a recording company. Have your characters attend a concert where the 'band' play a full song while the actors dance and cheer.   2) Promoting merch. The scene revolves around the merch which will be available on Walmart shelves before the movie is even released. Cute protagonist action figures are a guaranteed win. 7:29 I mean 90% of thors(the marvel character) mythology comes from marvel comics and what we see in the movies was established WELL before Disney's acquisition. Not to mention "Norse Mythology" is at best partially made up to at worst mostly made up considering the religion people worshipped in Scandinavia wasn't some strictly codified theology. No one wrote anything down; we only know what was passed down orally from person to person. This coupled with the less than peaceful Christianization of the Scandinavian region makes it so that what we know today is at best cobbled together.   Honestly, I clicked this video to hear why the movie sucked(because it does) I wasn't expecting a 10-minute video about a scene that barely lasts a couple minutes and is at best/worst a short call back. I don't think it's fair or makes sense to use this one PURPOSEFULLY purely comedic scene as an example of why this terrible movie is terrible. Directors are allowed to have their own creative styles and Taika simply maintaining his is not a fair knock against him. Creativity always has to be reigned-in by something be it finances, morals, or even some self-imposed limitation. Without limits, what you get has no coherence and it winds up being bloated. Futurama is a good example of this, I think. The first seasons on FOX were hilarious and smart with the writers always having to bump up against the limitations put on them by broadcast standards and practices and the FCC; the seasons on Comedy Central lacked any real focus, chased pop culture trends that now make a show about a fantastical future seem dated, and by-and-large just weren't funny or at least no where near as funny as the original run. Creativity always works best when it must be used to create the best product under limitations.

Honestly I feel like the only people who bash on Thor: Love and Thunder are people who expect Marvel movies to be more than what they are supposed to be. I've been a fan of Marvel through ups and downs and I came to realize that those movies are the most successful when they match the energy of the general public's expectation and not what critics seem to expect from them. My girlfriend never liked Marvel movies on the other hand but she seemed to enjoy the self awareness of certain Marvel movies. From Iron Man to Captain America 2, from Thor: Ragnarok to Black Panther which got her invested in the stories and tone of Infinity War and Endgame.  Critics are always shitting on exposition dialogue but when done in a different way it's suddenly a waste of time? My girlfriend for example particularly liked the Theater scene as a callback to Ragnarok and reminder of stuff that happened. She wasn't able to get through Thor 1 and 2 cause they were so stoic and serious, but this movie got her invested in Jane Foster by itself. I found it interesting that in Ragnorak the actors picked for the play: Matt Damon, Liam Hemsworth, and Sam Neil, all made sense in context. Hemsworth is obviously the brother of Chris, Damon is one of the most successful actors in Hollywood and a really handsome dude, just the kind of actor Loki would consider worthy to play him, and Sam Neil, like Anthony Hopkins, has a history of playing distinguished authority figures. I find it very rare when any individual gets majority control over a movie. Movie production crews are almost designed with checks and balances, which is nice to have to keep the director on pace. These other inputs often helps directors execute their vision. Even if a director is a visionary,  if they have poor execution, it's all irrelevant. Thor 4 would have benefited heavily from having more people pushing against or steering Taika. Movie sets aren't any different from another work environment in the sense they benefit from having people come together with opposing ideas and discuss what is better.

We've seen countless examples in the past, of studio interference ruining a movie, it happens all too often. But in this case, "Love and Thunder" is probably one of the worst examples of giving too much creative control to one guy. Disney probably thought, that with how well received Ragnar√∂k was, that Taika could do no wrong, big mistake. Ragnar√∂k, despite being a decent movie had it's flaws, the emphasis on comedy was always just shy of completely ruining it. Love and Thunder on the other hand was utterly overwhelmed by it, practically drowning what little story there was. I'm just glad Disney saw sense (which is rare), and kicked Taika out.

I objectively disliked Ragnarok, but on a second watch, it wasn't as immediately grating as my first time watching in the cinema. There were moments where it did ease up on the gags to at least give us a few minutes of poignancy. Not many, but Odin's death scene is one of them, as with the very end with the fall of Asgard. And the Loki moments were generally good when it's not overboard, such as him having a change of heart towards the end and forgoing his usual self-serving nature for the greater good.  So it's not that Taika doesn't understand the value of drama. It's just that instead of letting a dramatic moment hit home and sink in, he places greater value on comedy, to the point where it cheapens the film. That was what I disliked about Ragnarok and Love and Thunder. Not because it was trying to be funny, but because it was trying to be funny when it shouldn't.   Love and Thunder was too much of that. It's basically the problem of  Disney unwilling to trust its audience to sit still with heavy moments (hello, Pixar movies can be funny, charming and still gut punch you), so they cheapen the scene with gags.  This video breaking down the MCU and comparing with Wonder Woman is a great explanation then, and it's still relevant today. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w-QhdzQo66o  I thought with Avengers: Infinity War and Endgame, Disney finally learnt something from movies like Logan, and moved on from the pointless comedy to keep kids and parents happy. Truthfully, I was glad to see Thor serious again in Infinity War. Fat Thor in Endgame is a kind of self-deprecating humour that comes from Thor becoming depressed at not killing Thanos the first time. It's a tragic kind of humor that doesn't permeate across the entire film. That Thor: Love and Thunder regressed to cheap running gags of screaming goats is pretty emblematic of just how unwilling Disney is to move from its comfort zone. It knows whatever comes out with the MCU label, it's still going to make hundreds of millions of dollars.
When Cate Blanchet came out as Hella, I was like "Damn woman.....Looking good!" When Melissa McCarthy came out I was like "Oh for fuck sake!"

I am conflicted with love and Thunder. I genuinely think it was a fun film but the criticism is also justifiable.  The constant goofy comedic relief undermined what was seriously a great foundation of a story.  Jane dealing with cancer. We saw her genuinely afraid and vulnerable despite her power as lady Thor. Thor genuinely loves her and worries for her. Gors loss and the betrayal of the gods and his quest for vengeance fuelled by a fathers love of his lost daughter.  It was some really brilliant stuff.  The action was also at time top tier, particularly the fights against Gor. They were really well choreographed imo.  So I 100% understand why ppl disliked it.  But if I am honest I walked away at least content that I enjoyed the time I watched it. It most certainly could have been a heap better but I was not upset.

There's also one thing pretty much every scene should have - and in movies this is as close to a universal rule as you can get.  It's this:  There has to be some value within the scene that turns from positive to negative or negative to positive.  When this happens the scene turns.  Scenes which do not turn are a non-event.  They serve no purpose and should be removed.  This is more of a rule in screenwriting than novelization, primarily because every page which ends up on the screen costs money.  You cannot bore the audience and every scene must serve a purpose.
I wouldn't give Disney/Marvel a dime ... Disney has become such an un-American company. Walt Disney (the man) was all about the family and traditional American values. Today's Disney is about putting out as much merchandise (crap) as possible to make money and promoting woke anti-American ideas.

In Love and Thunder, Thor was already broken inside, and yet they still couldn‚Äôt do anything related to it! Still, even without the mental aspect - Gorr had so much wasted potential as a normal villain. He was supposed to be the ‚ÄúGod Butcher‚Äù but he killed one god. One! Even that was at the beginning, where he was being introduced and set up. After that, he was essentially like ‚ÄúDamn. This is a hell of a lot of work. Guess I‚Äôll just go to the wishing well and kill them all together.‚Äù, which was the plot of the entire movie. Then at the end, he doesn‚Äôt even use the wishing well for what he wanted to! This comment is going to be long. But I'm going to do it anyway. I'm gonna test one of my scenes from a book series I've been working on. I've got 3 books finished right now. Let's use one scene from the 3rd book. I feel like it's the best out of the books. Also the scene I will use might have no context but I think it should be enjoyable.  "Megatron: Devastator, Menasor, and Bruticus! Start the slaughter! Leave nothing alive in your wake!  Mixmaster and Scrapper transform and stop side by side. Both of their alt modes transform a bit with their back going up. Long haul transforms and gets himself onto the duo and connects to them. His body forming into a torso.  Hook transforms and gets onto Long Haul forming the body. Scavenger transforms and attaches to the right of Hook. Bonecrusher transforms and attaches to Hook's left side. Purple hands pop out of both Bonecrusher and Scavenger.  A head with red shades pops out from the top and a Decepticon insignia stands on his chest. Breakdown and Dead End stop and turn into feet and Motormaster attached himself to them as his alt mode changes into the middle body.  Dead End and Drag Strip attach to his sides and a head pops out of the top. Swindle and Brawl in their alt modes transform into feet and Onslaught attaches himself to them as his alt mode transforms into a body. Vortex and Blast Off attach to his sides and hands pop out.  At the top a head with red shades pops out. Devastator walks to an entrance and rips it open with his bare hands. Sideswipe, Sunstreaker, Wheeljack, and Cliffjumper turn around seeing Devastator. Sideswipe stabs the console with his sword, and it opens.  They run to the door as Devastator reaches for them.  Starscream: They have back up!  Starscream points to a ship. Megatron turns and sees an orange ship flying towards the city.  Megatron: Prime.  In the ship Optimius Prime sat at the front with Jazz to his left, and Bumblebee to his right. Chromedome was to Bumblebee's right. The Dinobots stood in the middle of the ship. Optimus turns his head to the Dinoebots.  Optimus Prime: Dinobots. Destroy Devastator!  Optimus turns his head back.  Grimlock: We love challenges like that!  Grimlock jumps down first followed by Slug, Sludge, Snarl, and Swoop. The ship flies over head toward the city while the Dinobots free fall toward Devastator. The Dinobots transformed midair and got closer to Devastator.  Devastator turns his attention to the Dinobots and before Grimlock could land a hit Devastator kicks Grimlock in the stomach away. The rest land while Swoop shoots missles at Devastator. Sludge charges at Devastator but he slams his fists down on Sludge's back.  Sludge falls onto his stomach and gets picked up. Devastator holds Sludge over his head and throws Sludge at Grimlock who transformed. He grabs Sludge but falls to the ground. Slug charges at Devastator's foot making Devastator tumble backward a bit.  Snarl whips his tail at Devastator's left foot making him tumble deeper into the building behind him. Menasor takes out his sword and it gets striked by lightning and Menasor strikes his sword down at Grimlock and Sludge. But the duo dodges it and Grimlock transforms.  He breathes fire on Menasor who covers his face from Sludge uses his tail and trips Menasor. Swoop shoots his missiles at Bruticus but he blocks it with Vortex's blades. Bruticus swipes his right hand at Swoop but misses.  Bruticus swipes up with his right hand and this time hits Swoop. Snarl charges at Bruticus foot and pushes him a bit before getting kicked into the air. Bruticus grabs a piece of metal bar and swings at Snarl. Snarl flies across the city. Slug and Sludge breathe fire on his feet.  Grimlock jumps over the duo in his alt mode and the duo follow him as Menasor swipes his sword down missing them. Slug and Sludge trip Bruticus with their tails and he falls onto Menasor.  Slug: They are strong. But not smart!  Sludge and Slug are knocked away by a blast from Devastator's blaster. Devastator shoots at Grimlock but misses. Grimlock runs and Devastator gives chase. The ship lands down on a platform near the dam that was close. The door on the side goes down and out comes Jazz.  He stays right at the door with his blaster out. Bumblebee rolls out right in front of Jazz. Chromedome goes to the right and takes out his blaster. The trio look around and Optimus exits running down the ramp before stopping. He looks up at Autobot City seeing it in ruins.  Optimus Prime: Get any Autobots you can find and get out of the city. Understood?  Jazz: Got it Prime.  Optimus stares at destruction.  Optimus Prime: Megatron must be stopped. No matter the cost."   1.Advancing the Plot: Ok. So how is this scene advancing the plot? Well Megatron is having his Combiners start the slaughter and Optimus arrives just in the nick of time. The Dinobots fight Menasor, Bruticus, and Devastator and at the end of the scene they had done their job in slowing down Megatron enough for Optimus.  2.Character Development: Megatron is shown to let his very powerful Combiners loose and shows no regard for their safety. The Decepticons seem to do just as their told. As if they are mindless. Like this is just another battle that is needed to win. And the Dinobots are shown to just go into a fight and try to win. They use their processors and win. They successfully took down 2 Combiners. But in the end Grimlock was chased by Devastator. And Optimus shows compassion for his soldiers. Wanting Jazz, Chromedome, and Bumblebee to try and get any other Autobot out of the city before they were next. And Optimus is willing to deal with the threat head on by himself.  3.World Building: This scene builds the world showing that the destruction and ruin of Autobot City. Showing that they were on Earth and came just in the nick of time. This also shows how the Autobots and Decepticons aren't invincible.  See. I filled all 3 of them out. Not perfect for the world building. But I could use another scene to basically do world building. Now if anyone wants to give it a shot. You can review the scene I put here.

That is a consistent problem with studios.   They have a good director who makes them a ton of money on a small, or limited budget film ---and then they think "Wait a minute, he made us10x our investment on some cheap films, if we give him 10x the money, then we will make 100x.  Let's do it." From that we get movies like "Cleopatra", or TGTBTU (which is bloated and over-rated),  Heaven's Gate, Waterworld, and so many more.   BTW, despite what people say, I put 2011 Space Odyssey in that category, too.  Film could have been so much better with tighter writing & editing.

So the movie starts with Christian Bale as Gorr watching his daughter die while he prays to a "god". He then encounters said being and finds this "god" to be a buffoon who doesn't care about mortal life. Gorr surmises that all of these "gods" are like this and sets out on a quest to end these beings who inflict or at least are wholly complicit in the suffering of sentient life throughout the universe. We then switch tracks to following one of these laughable deities, Thor. We open up on him causing utter destruction, humiliation, and ruin to mortals. Fitting Gorr's understanding of these gods perfectly. Thor then spends a large part of the film trying to crash a bacchanal of deities, apparently not the first one he has attended. We learn at that bacchanal that all of these gods used to routinely sacrifice sentient beings en masse for fun during their orgies. By implication, so did Thor.¬†  Thor shows little regard for mortal beings throughout any of this, and is wholly focused on his fellow gods. Even the one tie he had to the mortal world is now also a god. We find out that Gorr's true purpose is to reach the heart of all reality. There he can make a wish to unmake all these horrible, false gods. And these beings are confirmed to be fairly horrible at every turn by their actions in the film. Nothing in the movie shows us how they help anyone but themselves. And it even frequently implies that they harm others for sport and amusement. Sometimes by accident and sometimes intentionally.¬†  When Gorr eventually manages to achieve his task, he finds himself at the feet of the one, true monotheistic concept of deity. Gorr lives up to the name of the actor playing him. In this moment at the feet of God with a capital G, he's unable to wish for the harm of so many others simply to appease his own wrath or whims. All he can do is sacrifice his life to redeem one who was lost. There are 0 readings of this film that make sense to me where Thor is a hero and Gorr is a villain ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø  And that would be fine. There are plenty of stories where the protagonist and antagonist are switched and the latter is the hero and the former the villain. But this one doesn't seem to know that's the story it's telling. It seems to feel that we should protect the small percentage of the universe who have power and privilege gained on the backs of billions of lives wasted in suffering for their amusement, rather than rooting for the prodigal son who ventures down a dark path in his quest to redeem himself and protect the weak.   And that's what I think the problem with this film is.

This reminds me of the difference between the star wars ot and the prequels. Lucas was always the man with the creativity and the vision for the story. This was true in both instances. However, in the OT he surrounded himself with talented people who checked him and ultimately resulted in a great product. By the time of the prequels he was surrounded by yes men who just worshipped at the altar of Lucas so he wasn't challenged or checked by them. This results in a prequel trilogy which still has the vision and heart of the OT, but with much more wooden dialogue and poor execution of scenes and technology.

WHAT IS THE GOSPEL? The Gospel is good news: Your debt has been paid; Your penalty has been carried out. That‚Äôs what the word ‚ÄúGospel‚Äù means.   ‚ÄúPropitiation‚Äù in the Bible is defined as ‚Äúthe act of gaining or regaining the favor or goodwill of someone or something; the act of appeasement as in a sacrifice; specifically an atoning sacrifice.‚Äù   2 Corinthians 5:21 For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him.   Jesus allowed Himself to be the appeasement to the Father for all our sins. He was not forced to do this, but did so willingly. (John 10:18) Also, He gave Himself as the pure and acceptable sacrifice, not only for God‚Äôs chosen Jewish people, but for everyone in the world for all time. (John 10:16)   For just a brief moment of His agony, our Savior experienced what it would be like to be separated from the Father forever. This was the moment He dreaded the most of the entire crucifixion, when God would have to look away as His Son took on every sin this world would ever commit. That would‚Äôve been the moment when Jesus exclaimed; ‚ÄúMy God! My God! Why have You forsaken Me?‚Äù (Matthew 27:46)    Being a perfect and righteous God, He can tolerate no sin whatsoever. There are people who believe they have never sinned, but Romans 3:23-25 and Romans 6:23 sets this straight. Romans 3:23-25; ‚Äúfor all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, (24) and are justified by His grace as a gift, through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus, (25) whom God put forward as a propitiation by His blood, to be received by faith. This was to show God‚Äôs righteousness, because in His forbearance, He had passed over former sins.‚Äù This is emphasized in Psalm 103:12 that states our sins are removed ‚Äúas far as east is from west‚Äù. Only the perfect sinless blood of Jesus could accomplish this.   Going to Romans 6:23, we see just how the Father feels about sin, and just how important the sacrifice of our Savior really was; ‚ÄúFor the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.‚Äù   THE GOSPEL!   BELIEVE and RECEIVE Jesus' free gift of salvation: üìñ1 Corinthians 15: 1-4  Moreover, brethren, I declare unto you the GOSPEL which I preached unto you, which also ye have received, and wherein ye stand; By which also ye are SAVED, if ye keep in memory what I preached unto you, unless ye have believed in vain. For I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received, how that Christ DIED for our SINS according to the scriptures; And that he was BURIED, and that he ROSE again the third day according to the scriptures:     The only hope we have is Jesus. Jesus is the answer. He‚Äôs the only answer, and He‚Äôs the only hope. And His return for us as His church is our only hope. That‚Äôs what the good news is.   In fact, in 1 Thessalonians, the first epistle that the Apostle Paul wrote, he shares the gospel in the context of the Rapture in Chapter 4 of 1 Thessalonians, saying, for we believe that Jesus was crucified, buried, and rose again on the third day, and He‚Äôs coming back again one day. That‚Äôs the good news.   RELIGION SAYS DO. JESUS CHRIST SAYS DONE!!   Soon one life will be PAST and that which only was done for Jesus Christ will LAST!   üìñEphesians 1:13-14 13 In whom ye also trusted, after that ye heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation: in whom also after that ye believed, ye were sealed with that holy Spirit of promise, 14 Which is the earnest of our inheritance until the redemption of the purchased possession, unto the praise of his glory.   üìñ2 Corinthians 11:3 But I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ.   Do You Know God Personally? God LOVES you and offers a wonderful PLAN for your life.   God‚Äôs Love ‚ÄúGod so loved the world that He gave His one and only Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life‚Äù   God‚Äôs Plan [Jesus speaking] ‚ÄúI came that they might have life, and might have it abundantly‚Äù [that it might be full and meaningful‚Äù (John 10:10).   Why is it that most people are not experiencing the abundant life? Because‚Ä¶Man is SINFUL and SEPARATED from God. Therefore, he cannot know and experience God‚Äôs love and plan for his life.   Man Is Sinful ‚ÄúAll have sinned and fall short of the glory of God‚Äù (Romans 3:23). Man was created to have fellowship with God; but, because of his stubborn self-will, he chose to go his own independent way, and fellowship with God was broken. This self-will, characterized by an attitude of active rebellion or passive indifference, is an evidence of what the Bible calls sin.   Man Is Separated ‚ÄúThe wages of sin is death‚Äù [spiritual separation from God] (Romans 6:23). Man is continually trying to reach God and the abundant life through his own efforts, such as a good life, philosophy, or religion ‚Äì but he inevitably fails. The only way to bridge this gulf‚Ä¶   He Died in Our Place ‚ÄúGod demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us‚Äù (Romans 5:8).    He Rose From the Dead ‚ÄúChrist died for our sins‚Ä¶He was buried‚Ä¶He was raised on the third day, according to the Scriptures‚Ä¶He appeared to Peter, then to the twelve. After that He appeared to more than five hundred‚Ä¶‚Äù (1 Corinthians 15:3-6).    He Is the Only Way to God ‚ÄúJesus said to him, ‚ÄòI am the way, and the truth, and the life; no one comes to the Father, but through Me‚Äô‚Äù (John 14:6).   This shows that God has bridged the gulf which separates us from Him by sending His Son, Jesus Christ, to die on the cross in our place to pay the penalty for our sins. It is not enough just to know this‚Ä¶We must individually RECEIVE Jesus Christ as Savior and Lord; then we can know and experience God‚Äôs love and plan for our lives.   We Must Receive Christ ‚ÄúAs many as received Him, to them He gave the right to become children of God, even to those who believe in His name‚Äù (John 1:12)    We Receive Christ Through Faith ‚ÄúBy grace you have been saved through faith; and that not of yourselves, it is the gift of God; not as a result of works, that no one should boast‚Äù (Ephesians 2:8,9).When We Receive Christ, We Experience a New Birth ( John 3:1-8).   We Receive Christ by Personal Invitation [Christ speaking] ‚ÄúBehold, I stand at the door and knock; if any one hears My voice and opens the door, I will come in to him‚Äù (Revelation 3:20). Receiving Christ involves turning to God from self (repentance) and trusting Christ to come into our lives to forgive our sins and to make us what He wants us to be. Just to agree intellectually that Jesus Christ is the Son of God and that He died on the cross for our sins is not enough. Nor is it enough to have an emotional experience. We receive Jesus Christ by faith, as an act of the will. All the work of salvation was done by Jesus Himself. He took upon Himself the punishment for our sins as well as the sins themselves, and went to the cross and paid for every sin that would ever be committed throughout history.   WHAT DOES IT MEAN TO BE BORN AGAIN?...   The phrase ‚Äúborn again‚Äù applies to people who have accepted Jesus as their Savior or Redeemer. The born again soul realizes that they are a sinner (Romans 3:23) and that the penalty for that sin is death (Romans 6:23). To rectify the circumstances, God sent His only Son to die in their place, to take the punishment for sin (Romans 5:8). After Jesus‚Äô death, He arose from the dead (1 Corinthians 15:3-6). Jesus is the only way to God (John 14:6) and He provides the blessing of salvation. Each person has the choice to receive or reject God‚Äôs gift through faith (Ephesians 2:8-9) and experience new birth (John 3:1-8).    WHAT IS BIBLICAL REPENTANCE? Biblical repentance is God centered repentance comes from the greek word 'METANOIA' which means change of one's mind and heart which imparts a new direction to the whole life. Repent (To repent, in relation to salvation, is to change your mind from unbelief to belief in Jesus Christ. To being dead in your sins to a new creature in Christ) and believe in the Gospel.   The ABCs of Salvation:   The A is for: Admit or acknowledge that you‚Äôve sinned, that you need the Savior. Romans 3:10 says, ‚ÄúThere is no one righteous, not even one.‚Äù Romans 3:23 tells us why. It‚Äôs because ‚ÄúAll have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.‚Äù Romans 6:23 says, ‚ÄúThe wages of sin is death but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.‚Äù   The B very simply is for: Believe in your heart that Jesus Christ is Lord. I feel like this movie is an allegory for adulthood. Thor is trying his best to recapture the coolness he had before, but his spark is gone, and he just comes off as cringe and trying too hard. The movie somehow manages to capture that strange awkwardness and clumsiness of being an adult, and is somehow refreshingly relatable.  Also, I thought that all the stuff about the gods as an allegory about billionaires, modern capitalism, and cataclysmic climate change, was pretty clever, if not a bit on the nose.  Despite its many flaws, the movie did eventually win me over at the end.

Agreed: Taika's got talent, but a little goes a long way. "Ragnarok"? Just enough Taika. "Love & Thunder"? Apparently *way* too much Taika.  Thor in "Ragnarok" loosened up & was (to me) just funny enough, without losing his edge of bada**ery. (And Dr. Strange was in *command* of magic in that movie, even "owning" Loki.) Then only a few MCU movies later, Thor (and Strange) were...kind of pathetic, reduced nearly to figures of fun -- in their own films! -- in service to "The Message." Bait, meet switch. Title character becomes sidekick.  (See also: "Mad Max: Fury Road." For God's sake, this supposed legend gets his own car stolen from him by some random punks, then gets tied to his own hood or otherwise sidelined for most of the movie. Miller, if you'd told me this was going to be a Furiosa movie, I'd've still bought a ticket, and it was objectively a well-crafted film. But I resent the chicanery.)  Nobody *wants* parameters or constraints, but I firmly believe almost everybody *needs* them. Tracks don't "oppress" trains, riverbanks don't "oppress" rivers, schedules & budgets don't "oppress" artists -- they guide them, help keep them on track.  One of the worst things that can happen to an artist is being allowed to do whatever he wants, because he's too big for anyone to say "no" to anymore. "OMG, George, of *course* we want more 'Star Wars'! Sure, write & direct the whole thing yourself, after barely writing anything for the past couple decades! It'll be *fine*!" Etc.

This whole thing reminds me of the Avatar TV show, that fake anime some Americans put together. In the final seasons of both The Last Airbender and The Legend of Korra they had recap shows. In TLA they did it by way of a theater scene with the main cast watching a bunch of Fire Nation actors portray them. It was alternately hilarious, awkward, and poignant and it stands as one of the best and most memorable episodes in a series I regard as a towering achievement (especially given that it's supposed to be children's entertainment). In TLoK, instead of repeating themselves, a pair of main characters plot how they'd make a "mover" (the in-universe version of a movie) about their adventures, with the Tony Stark-like inventor/investor character and one of the main male characters stuck on a boat or a wagon or something (I don't really remember) and that episode stands as one of the best ones of a series that, while perhaps not as good as TLA was still pretty darn good. I think it's a credit to the creators and writers. They didn't crawl up their own asses and let the hype get to them and instead of repeating themselves like Waititi tries to do here they came up with a clever way to accomplish a similar goal and made it memorable in a different way.

Writer /Director is always a red flag and almost always a bad idea. They are 2 different jobs requiring 2 different sets of talents.  Even George Lucas' Episode IV was only the success it was because he had close friends able to tell him "no, there's a better way to do this."  Taika Waititi should've immediately been pulled from Lady Thor when he said "the audience doesn't know what it wants until I give it to them."  Translated, he's saying, "I'm such an egotistical narcissist that I don't care to understand what the customer wants." If you don't know what your customer wants, it's blind luck if you make the right product. You're throwing darts blindfolded after being spun in a few circles and just hoping you hit the wall the board is on, never mind the dartboard or actual bullseye.  What I like most about Critical Drinker's reviews is that he squeezes more entertainment and information into a product that has 5% of the viewer's time requirement compared to what he's reviewing. The Drinker understands what his audience wants, humor (entertainment) and information, and he provides it in a concise, useful format that respects his audience's time.  As it is, I was never going to watch Lady Thor. I can't stand the hypocrite Natalie Portman, the narcissist Taika Waititi, or the Abrams-esque over the top effects used to hide lack of story. I would like to thank the Drinker for valuing my time and confirming that this is a movie I didn't need to see and wouldn't have enjoyed.

To be fair I wholeheartedly hated Thor:Ragnarok so I watched Love & Thunder with a huge amount of low expectations and only because it was on D+ and I had nothing else to do that evening. I was surprisingly disappointed again.   I just can't bear all the lighthearted and mostly meaningless humor that gets vomited on you every 3-5 minutes in a setting that should be darker and "moodier" compared to the rest of Marvel, the first 2 movies were bad but at least they were bad just because they were done badly, not because they were inherently flawed in their origin. People complained too much about Thor being over the top dramatic about its plot but that's how it should be, you need something dramatic to balance the overall lightness of the MCU. Now everything is just a funny adventure without many stakes because you know that at the end of the movie the big bad guy will be dealth with and (almost) everyone will be ok, it's no fun to not feel the danger. I also believe that Loki and Thanos hard carried the MCU simply because they were antagonists that didn't just die after their first appearence, I honestly hope that the MCU does not start killing/removing main or side characters at the end of each movie like they started doing since Endgame.  I confess I liked the first moments of Ragnarok up until Odin's death, the the movie started tanking for me, yeah some of the jokes were good but the overall tone was leaving me with a bad aftertaste in my mouth, as if I was eating something with too much sugar. Love & Thunder left me with that feeling multiplied tenfold.  tl:dr:  Didn't like ragnarok, liked this one even less, MCU bad since Endgame and was barely holding by before that.

As I've stated previously, the movie made money.  Box Office was around $760 Million, per Wikipedia, on a Budget of $250 Million.  If you take into account the cost of Advertising and Marketing, the total cost of this movie was around $500 Million, then the movie made $250 Million.  As long as today's audiences continue to go see this garbage, Phase 5 will be successful after this very mediocre Phase 4.  That's not saying Marvel/Disney was probably somewhat disappointed the movie only made a 1/4 of a Billion dollars, but it did make that money.  I've only seen one movie since March of 2017 at the theatre and that was Spider-man No Way Home.  The last movie b4 which was the Disney Remake of "Beauty and the Beast", was a subpar remake, to say the least.     I'm not the demographic these movies are geared for, but it's still a terrible product Disney/Marvel is putting out to the public.  Every genre has copycats and rehashes/recycles stories from a successful show that started the genre.  A case in point is the Western Series of the 1950s through the early 1970s like "Gunsmoke" and the Detective Shows of the 1970s to mid-1980s like Columbo.  However, each show had its own identity.  "Starsky and Hutch" was a completely different show than "Kojak".  Even the Westerns were different in their own way.  "Wagon Train" was different than "Gunsmoke" which was different than "Bonanza".  Heck, "The Wild Wild West" combined the Western with the Spy genre of the mid-1960s.  You could tell immediately which show you were watching by the music of the show or its theme songs.  That seems to be lacking these days.  You're lucky to get 15 seconds of a theme song in today's shows.    Most people would debate this as "NCIS" as opposed to "Bones" and even that compared to "Law and Order - SVU".  I agree, but to me, these shows are the exception to the rule.  Most shows today have the same formula as other shows, and one could make that claim for shows from the 1950s through the 1990s.  However, I stress the fact again, those shows had their own way of scenes "Progressing the plot", "Developing the characters", and "World Building".  Let's take a look at one of the most beloved movies of all time.  Compare the original "Star Wars, Episode IV - A New Hope" and how that approaches those three rules as opposed to "Star Wars, Episode VII - The Force Awakens".  There's no comparison.          As long as Marvel/Disney makes money on these low-quality movies and TC Shows, the trend will continue and Marvel Phase 5 & Phase 6 will continue to be somewhat successful.
I wanna know how they got Shattered-Mjolnir in that glass case. Aside from elevators (and Vision), it‚Äôs already been established in prior movies that unworthy people cannot lift Mjolnir, nor can machinery like cranes. An elevator can lift Mjolnir if Thor (or another worthy person) ‚Äúplaces‚Äù (I‚Äôm using that term loosely) it on that elevator, same thing with a helicarrier (and why it got heavy for Hulk, but not heavy enough to crash the helicarrier in The Avengers).  So how did they get the pieces of Shattered-Mjolnir in that glass case? The case is elevated up by more than 4 feet, so I highly doubt they dug 5 feet down all around Mjolnir, and built that establishment around the site. Otherwise the area would look like a crater, sitting much lower than the rest of New Asgard. Either that, or they excavated the ENTIRE area of New Asgard to sit flush with the pieces of Mjolnir. Doubtful.  The most likely case is that they had Thor pick up the pieces of Mjolnir and place them on that pedestal. Which kinda ruins the whole point of the pedestal/glass case in the first place, but whatever.  All I know for certain is that I spend too much time thinking about stuff that the writers prolly came up with while they were taking a shit, and couldn‚Äôt care less if it makes sense or not.

It's what I call the Colin Chapman principle. Chapman was the head of Lotus cars back in the day, and he was obsessed with weight reduction. He's reported to have said that "every part must have at least two jobs." So the engine would be part of the car's frame, etc, eliminating redundant parts. This works in storytelling, too. If your scene can accomplish two or all three of the Drinker's listed goals, it feels smart, efficient, and lightweight. You never make the audience feel like they're wasting their time. Don't waste a scene by only giving it one job. (Or worse, no jobs.)

You Hate Everything Which Makes Your Opinion About Anything Meaningless.
1) I've had that same criticism about the Thor universe appropriating and rewriting a cultural religion and heritage ever since I learned about Thor from the comics and Saturday morning cartoons. Imagine the hubris needed to take gods of another culture and make them superhuman, then debase them in your universe for slapstick. Would you do that with Shiva? Anansi? Pele? Mohammed? If not, why do that to the Old Gods of the Norse and Germanic peoples, who had their entire mythos already purged by centuries of over zealous Christians?   2) By comparison, I adore the video game Okami. I found it to be a charming, if childish,  adaptation of well known Japanese myths. The differences between that game and Marvel's Thor? Okami stays within the existing mythology, with all kinds of characters and settings popping up. Ammy's character doesn't deviate from that of the canonical Amaterasu, being somewhat mischievous yet self sacrificing, with an ego and questionable attractions to boot. But Thor? It rewrites relationships and histories, it bastardizes settings in favor of jokes and villains of the week, it doesn't respect the source material half as much as even a T rated game with boob jokes did with a pun. (Okami = wolf, ≈å-kami = great god). And no, I'm not saying that Okami is a perfect adaptation or cultural representation, but it sure does respect Japanese myths better than Ragnarok did with, well, the actual Ragnarok or Fenrir or Jormungandr or where is Sleipner... or right, censored worse than Disney's Mount Olympus. (Seriously, they want to be progressive so much just tell that story, let alone give us the original Mystique fathering Nightcrawler and/or Rogue arcs they wanted.)

I'm kind of mad because Bale as Gorr was so utterly wasted and is probably the best MCU villain they've had besides Thanos himself (even more than Loki, who isn't really a villain after the Avengers) and Christian Bale ran rings around virtually everyone else in the acting department, but the writing and movie itself was so laughably awful that it strips him of his menace by-proxy. There's talk about scenes when Gorr flayed his tattoos off and did some seriously dark stuff; whilst I'm not saying all of it should have been in the movies, some of it SHOULD have been, as it would easily lend more gravitas and weight to the drama, weight that was-and increasingly IS- missing in the MCU as of late. There's no room for the drama to breathe, no place for the villains to have proper clout: its just deadpan stares and snarky quips, and behold; the villain is nothing but a joke themselves. Most writers and directors (and writer-directors) need oversight. There's a prevailing idea that the studio is just trying to "keep you down, man!" They're not. They want great movies too. They may be wrong in their approach at times. But they want to put out a hit. Just compare the first two Star Wars trilogies. Lucas had oversight on the 1st, and was forced to hone his vision. The 2nd he had free rein to do whatever. And in my opinion, it was a mess.
