Taika Waititi did a very good job with "Jojo Rabbit", and Season 1 of his "Reservation Dogs" was an excellent effort, too. In "Reservation Dogs" he did excellent work in portraying the real problems that Native Americans face in their daily lives, such as suicide, alcoholism, young people running away from home, and things like that - problems that all communities face in one degree or another, but which were so well in Reservation Dogs. Season 2 did not have a bad start, but then he took a turn south with the latter episodes of Season 2, with his rather base and vulgar portrayals of Native American women. How does Waititi imagine that depicting Native American women as low-lifes obsessed with erotic toys, can help (if he ever had it in mind) those communities overcome the perception in some minds that they are disposable people, worthy only of lamentable dead-end lives, or foul deaths, at the hands of those who perpetuate the brutal trend of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women (MMIW)? Maybe Waititi is just a Pacific Islander version of the Martha's Vineyard liberal, who professes much concern, but not involvement, for the welfare of his fellow human beings.

Love & Thunder is a good example of "art without challenges". When a famous director is given too much freedom, or noone dares to challenge his decisions, he lack essential perspective on his own work. Producers weren't particularly interested to challenge Waititi in the first place : they don't know what to do with Thor in general (and Phase 4). On top of that, Waititi himself has is own preferences : stories involving children, nostalgia, and parody . But he's stuck with Thor, a character that requires a more "shakespearian" or epic style. Love & Tunder is the expected product of all of this.

I think Taika Waititi is classically ADHD - tons of ambition, energy, and creativity, but he lacks focus and organisational skills. He does his best work when he has tight parameters and clear goals, such as in advertising, or when he‚Äôs with a team that can anchor him and help him with executive functioning, as he does with his Wellington collaborators in What We Do in the Shadows. Having become super-successful, he has been given creative free rein, and appears to have jettisoned the team approach, so scatter-gun chaos ensues.

A good representation of Taika Waititi is the characters he plays in Free Guy "Antwan" mixed a bit with his "Black Beard" from Our Flag Means Death. These 2 roles sum up Waititi perfectly and should tell you everything you will need to know about his writing ability. Waititi can only think in 1 dimension and that is childish comedy, which means his writing of Jojo Rabbit, What We Do in the Shadows, and  Our Flag Means Death were going to be good. He understands this genre well, and for the most part will do a good job at it. But anything requiring action, drama, romance, and even anything meaningful or moving he will fall flat on his face every time! And so I present to you his Dumpster Fire Opus: Thor: Love and Thunder.
I agree with this. around the 20 min mark, I noticed scenes just started feeling... rushed. Key moments are being glanced at for a few moments, and just simple quality-of-life shots are cut out. for instance, a bit of a spoiler warning, after a building collapses on our unarmed heroes, it suddenly cuts to our heroes completely clean, armed, and ready to fight. Look at what endgame or even the original avengers did: separation of the characters, slow recovery with character developments or side plots, and eventually getting back in the fight. It just overall felt like I was watching a youtube video of "cool combat cutscenes only" to a video game like Mortal Kombat rather than a story actually being developed in a scene and it slowed down the tempo to allow the point to really stick out.
I think all scenes should advance the story in a cohesive way.  It doesn't matter if you are developing a character or worldbuilding, if it isn't absolutely required to tell the story, it should be jettisoned.  One of the biggest problems with storytelling circa current year is the self-indulgent jerk-off scenes that plague modern movies and television shows.

You have a hit and a great run and everyone loves you and you think you're mad of Teflon and so did Taika. Over the course of Thor's character development across every MCU appearance, he experienced something like what happened to Homer Simpson and Michael Scott.  At first they were somewhat serious people around whom humorous situations were created.  Homer was in a perpetual bad mood because of his son's shenanigans.  Then he became "Jerkass Homer", with increasingly unbelievable situations that served only to lob jokes at the audience.  Homer began as a hardworking family man making the best of his life, only to get launched into space with Buzz Aldrin.  Thor began as a god, but slowly devolved into a buffoon with no self-awareness.  Instead of creating humorous situations, he simply became the butt of the jokes.  Not to belabor the point further, but the differences between Star Treks IV and V were that IV had warmth and humor, while V had sight gags and comedy.

"Thor: Love and Thunder" does to the MCU what "Teen Titans Go" does to the DC Universe. The difference is that "Teen Titans Go" is meant to be an immature parody that's not connected to the rest of DC's movie and TV show continuity, while "Thor: Love and Thunder" is meant to be an immature parody that is connected to the rest of the MCU continuity. That's what pisses off fans so much. Any other longtime Marvel Comics fans will remember Marvel's comic book series "What The?!" The tone of "Thor: Love and Thunder" was very much the same.  Also, compare the use of Led Zeppelin's "Immigrant Song" in "Thor: Ragnarok" to the inclusion of Guns 'N Roses songs in "Thor: Love and Thunder". "Immigrant Song" references Norse mythology. It wasn't just a classic rock song. "Thor: Love and Thunder" didn't understand that. It just wanted classic rock songs. It tried to recreate the success of its predecessor through superficial means. From a comic book artist's perspective, this is like how Rob Liefeld became famous copying other people artwork to make flashy pictures without understanding human anatomy, perspective, and important things like that.

I didn't think Love & Thunder was terrible, but it was definitely mediocre, and I blame that on two main flaws:  (1) It seemed like the writers (or just Taika?) couldn't let serious moments breathe. One of the best scenes in the movie is when Jane looks in the mirror as Mighty Thor, then drops the hammer and we see her sick and exhausted as just Jane... until suddenly Valkyrie shows up and they make a really dumb joke about a grenade being a speaker and playing Destiny's Child to end the scene. That forced joke destroyed what would have otherwise been a poignant moment; and that trend continued throughout the movie.  (2) As great a villain as Gorr was, his origin was so damn rushed. He's walking in the desert and then the gods just *happen* to manifest in front of him. Then they just *happen* to leave out the only sword that can kill them, and *tell him* that it can; and when Gorr gets angry, they just imitate Willy Wonka with a lame "no, wait, don't" while he picks up the Necrosword and murders them. Like... what? How the hell did these gods even survive as long as they did if they're that stupid? And the worst part is, if this was a result of cutting for time, they could easily have cut half the unnecessary jokes from issue #1 to make time for a better origin depiction.
I hope taika can learn to tone it down when it comes to injecting his style of humor into his movies because I think he‚Äôs a really good director, what stops him from being great is his lack of discipline. He‚Äôs got the humor part down pat, and there are some slivers in love and thunder that could‚Äôve been great had they had more time to develop i.e. Bales portrayal of gorr and Jane learning to accept her inevitable fate. I think the big failure with love and thunder was Thors arc. He basically just retreads all his previous arcs and then they tack him with a kid at the end.

I think this is also an example of what happens when you don't exercise self-imposed restraint during the creative process.   Simply put, while creating art, the artist is certainly allowed to become overly ambitious and self-indulgent to a certain degree, but even s/he needs to know where and how not to cross the line at certain points, especially when taking factors into account like the eager collaboration of cast and crew needed to make it work, budgetary and time constraints, etc. When creating something all your own, you need to test your limits without going overboard, otherwise you end up doing a disservice to your own project. I'm not saying you should compromise your own vision to pander to those who lack perception of what the art piece could and SHOULD be - and certainly DON'T pander to the lowest common denominator and ESPECIALLY out of monetary gains or playing it safe - but there's a certain way to make it work and you need to strike a proper balance in order to make it work that way exactly.

Thor: L&T is the Austin Powers 2 of the franchise. Austin Powers was great for what it was, and had a lot of funny jokes. It also had heart. The sequel was Mike Myers rehashing a lot of the same stuff, but in a way that was a sort of "nod and wink" kind of approach. "Really guys, this is funny stuff!" Only it wasn't. L&T is the result of Taika Waititi being high on his own supply, and as you stated, not having anyone to help reign him in at all. Instead, it's a mess of lame jokes, unfunny bits, and good action sequences. I appreciated them trying to tie up the Thor and Jane storyline, and to an extent they accomplished that, but it should have been done in a much better movie. Christian Bale transcended the script a bit, and at least gave a good performance. But it just didn't work, and I found myself leaving the theater totally unfulfilled. Ragnarok wasn't perfect, but it was a far better film, and at least had the good sense to know when it needed that push/pull between the humor and a more serious tone. This movie felt like it was written by a 12 year old who can't get enough fart jokes.
Waititi's story is an old one in Hollywood. Take a talented director who has experienced some success and then give him a blank check and unrestrained power over a would-be blockbuster and watch as his hubris results in a dumpster fire. Those of a certain age will remember Michael Cimino, who made two big critical and commercial hits, Thunderbolt and Lightfoot and The Deer Hunter, and was given a huge (for the day) budget and total creative control over his next film- and came up with Heaven's Gate, one of the biggest bombs in Hollywood history.

The last statement you made underscores the issue with Hollywood and remakes. It sounds like, because he had little to no oversight, it exposed the fact that whatever made the previous movie great, he did not understand. The ideas and themes did not solely come from him. It came from a collective that was able to properly weigh in, cut out, and make the ideas work. Like you said, its not that he isn't a good director, or that he isn't creative. He's good by himself, he's better when he's combined with others. He's like a good Old Fashion - you can make it without bitters, but it's better with them.

This breakdown makes me realize that this scene could have worked with a little of that discipline thing. Because the scene wouldn't check as many boxes, serving largely as both a plot reminder and a callback to the previous film, it could have had its presence justified with...efficient run time. How? Have Natalie Portman's hooded character walk up in disguise and see the Thor and Loki and Odin actors beginning Odin's death scene...just a moment. Then have Portman walk towards the display case for Mjolnir...she hears a "roarrrrr!!!", looks behind her to the stage and sees the McCarthy Hela having caught the stage Mjolnir, which then shatters. Portman then looks into the case (swinging camera first person perspective) to see the pieces of the hammer for the first time. And there you go...you get your callback, you get your (presumably) amusing reveal of a McCarthy Hela, and you allow the audience to more explicitly recall exactly what happened to the hammer in the first place, all in a fraction of the time and interlacing the stage bit and Portman coming to the hammer.

CounterPoint(second attempt) : Why Thor Love & Thunder was actually good, and also, by far the best Thor movie in the series: 1. There's an actual plot. In previous Thors, there hardly was _any_ . They were a bunch of random sewed together scenes, with no underlying themes or structure in them. Stuff like the main villain getting done by random third party introduced at and forgotten after first 5 mins in Raggie ect... 2. There's actually a LOT better/more themes in thor 4. Themes In Ragnarok? Becoming "King" & Asgardians are the people, not the country. Themes in Thor 4? parental love, revenge theme,  gods = bad? ,  choosing between identities (thor, natalie/fthor) ,  space-viking-hood = good, masculinity=good,  heck ton of viking culture/mentality, parenting +viking culture related to parenting. Thor Finally becomes Odin. The people Accept him As KING over their "king". Really, I can't stretch enough, how pleased I was with the viking emphasize, in today's "feminine"& "anti-masculine" culture. They all want to die in battle and go to Valhalla? THE KIDS ARE TAUGHT TO FIGHT FROM CHILDHOOD, and "That's ok!"??  FCK YEAH! As a Nord myself, I fcking accept this. 3. The whole movie is not 100% "comedy". Ragnarok was so freaking overdone with that crap, it was disgusting. Here, it's toned down by 60%-70%(still a lot), and some of it is actually good/thematically solid. And it actually has counterbalancing sad/serious elements: the whole God Butcher storyline, Stage 4 cancer? Thors lovelife =they fell apart, they finally get together again, and she immediately dies? Serious topics here. 4. The CGI was amazing compared to all the previous marvel movies. Actually interesting/decent/varying borderline Limbo (game) like CGI creatures over generic non face copypaste mass monsters. The fights were insanely good looking (I'm almost never impressed with them, coming from an Anime Background, where things are generally twice better). 5. The female characters weren't surpassing Thor. Natalie's abilities are semi-explainable trough her capability to calculate trajectories better than Thor could (splitting hammer). She also showed critical/strategical thinking in fights, which is 100% better than being bruteforce-stronger than Thor. Valkyrie was borderline bareable & very toned down. Still got good character building (just wants to fight/die along her sisters again, finds a new one in FThor ect. ) 6. Christian Bale was freakishly good. 7. Nord God vs Greek God supremacy ++ :) 8. Some of the jokes were absolutely hilarious. :D The stupid cupcake God with anime googly eyes for a face? The Screaming Goats, which were 100% horrible design 10 years ago, equally horrible now, actually got funnier the more they spammed it, opposed to Pitch Meeting's opinion. :D The theoter presentation in the beginning was actually a good one imo. I hate theater ^^' but that's just at the edge of bearable/cringe enough to love it & feel culturally enlightened. 9. The Rock person was one of the only saving graces from Ragnarok. He's hilarious, and while they didn't use him to his fullest extend here, he was still a good addition. Borderline story writing cheat to have him psychoanalyze someone untactfully as a joke, or make a stupid lame ass story exposition in the beginning/end. 10. Fcking great story building for Thor to get a kid like that, to teach  the way's of the Vikings. :D Calling that the next thor is being cynical. 11. Actually tear jerking scenes. None of the previous thors have made me (a bit softie) feel anything of the sort. But man did the GodBucher wishing for his daughter to come to life, only to realize she'll have no one, and then get confirmation that Thor will take care of her... fcking beautiful.  those might be the main points. Anyone got something to add here? Pacing was great, Female thor was hot/natalie can still act (although not her best performance by any metric) and uh. yeah. the Gods could've been done better. More horrible ect. Imagine if Re;zero's writer was on that team... xd The sword def needed a proper background, but yeah. def good enough. :) 8.3 vs ragnaroks 6.3 (being generous).

This can only be one of three possibilities. He either didn't write the first scene, and thus didn't comprehend its importance, but decided to replicate it in the sequel because it was funny and worked the first time. Or he did write the first scene but another more competent writer improved upon it by making it relevant. Or, he did write the first scene intentionally having purpose in the story, though possibly without realising it, but just didn't care to make it relevant for the sequel.  Neither possibility is good.

This movie could have worked if it had leant in one direction or the other. An anthology of Thor with the Guardians as they have their adventures, leaning right in to the silliness. Or you do the story with Gorr going after the gods and Jane Foster dealing with her cancer but you go down the more serious route, for whatever reason they decided to mash the silliness of the first option with the seriousness of the second and the result was that the silliness wasn't funny because it felt forced and for the most part played no real part in driving the serious part of the story and the serious part of the story didn't work because any tension or stakes would immediately get sidelined by the next bit of silliness. Maybe I'm just an old fart, but why the hell can't people stay in their lane when it comes to the workplace.  Hire a director to direct, not have total godlike control over every aspect of a movie.  It's the same with the 2005 Doctor Who series with a showrunner being in overall control of the show and writing most of the episodes.  Which just means that the whole show suffers if you don't like that person's vision or writing ability.  In classic Doctor Who the writers were varied and reported to a script/story editor, who in turn reported to the producer.  There were too many creative people involved for any one person's ego or lack of talent to mess things up.  Why should a director automatically get the right to write a movie as well?

This just goes to validate my theory that some of the most memorable movies in American Cinema are that way because of hard limitations on the creative team that required talent and imagination to overcome. In Jaws the mechanical shark broke down constantly so Spielberg had to dip into Hitchcock level movie making tricks to build suspense. The wrath of Khan had a fraction of the budget that Star Trek the motion picture had because the lack of oversight on the original movie gave Gene Roddenberry the chance to make what amounts to being a bloated mess.

1. Character Development: the scene in love and thunder develops Valkyrie's characters. She as king has commissioned this play for tourists. And when matched with previous scenes it helps inform the audience of how shallow and sanitized Asgard is and why she wants to join Thor for a real exciting adventure leaving her kingdom to save the kids.  2. Moves the Plot Along: directly from this scene we then see tourists visit the hammer and before we saw much of New Asgard so plot wise this tells us the audience Jane is in New Asgard as a tourist which was set up earlier and we see her afterwards with the group looking at the remennts of mjolnir.   3. World building: Again the former great super power Asgard is now a tourist trap a shallow and hollow but more grounded and commoner version it's grand operatic self. Also implies that theater is a common past time in New Asgard and not just for Loki's narssasistic enjoyment but that Asgard likes having these plays. Also tells us the audience what happens before in ragnorak a bit   Bonus if funny- This is subjective and depends on the person. I thought it was funny maybe drinker didn't. It's always refreshing to see a big name Youtuber bring up the Marvel vs. Myth issue. Most of the pagan community, myself included, tries to remain good-natured when it comes to the Marvel depiction of Nordic gods. I do appreciate seeing my faith explored and introduced to new people. It doesn't need to be highly accurate or reverent (and, oh boy, it isn't). But recently... well, if we were talking about an Abrahamic religion here there'd at least have been pissed-off people in the street outside of Marvel Headquarters. There'd be calls to cancel such 'n' such and calls to fire so 'n' so. I'm not proposing anything like that but it'd be nice to see that the director consulted with a real life expert (an expert in Nordic myth, a historian, a heathen they met at the gym idc SOMEONE). A little respect goes a long way; instead we get Taika Waititi outright stating that his goal is to achieve the exact opposite.  Obviously, Taika Waititi is in a position to care very little whether I buy or support his work and, as far as I can tell, he blatantly relishes any offense he stands to cause me or any other pagan. Disney, the many-headed monster itself, cares even less and doooon't even get me started on the state of their comics ü§¨What I can do- what everyone can do- is decline when I'm asked or expected to buy their garbage. And I do. Though I support the creators who watch it when I won't, who also bring some much-needed attention to the ignorance and disrespect that goes into writing these movies.

I feel like the addition of Melissa McCarthy to the reenactment play in Love & Thunder was meant to be a mix of comedy, and inclusion (for plus sized people?).... but really ended up achieving the exact opposite thing...  being a fat joke at Melissa McCarthy's expense. So much of the "inclusiveness" in movies achieves the exact opposite of what these writers intend to do.... they actually reinforce stereotypes.... Let's have a plus sized woman do a parody of Cate Blanchett.... we don't take Melissa seriously here, because she is a stark contrast to Blanchett's portrayal of Hela. So the audience laughs at McCarthy because she is chubby, and goofy, and these laughs are ultimately at her expense. Yet another example of the hollow inclusiveness that plagues the modern blockbuster.

Without a doubt Quentin Tarantino is one of the most indulgent directors ever but for whatever reason he's also incredibly good at what he does and surprisingly practical. I've seen a little behind the scenes and producer Lawrence Bender noted that Tarantino would kvetch about the budget which was odd because that was his job and the director usually tries to forget about that kind of thing. The one scene that I think best sums up Tarantino is when he plays an unnamed bad guy in Planet Terror, the Grindhouse movie directed by Robert Rodriguez, he's about to have his way with the main character and when it's noted she's lost a leg he leerily says "easier access." The last Marvel movie I intentionally watched is The Avengers back when it first released. I watched 4/5 of Captain Marvel when I went over to a friends house to chill, unfortunately. Most recently I watched NWH with my nephew reluctantly, with which I was pleasantly  surprised. Since I started consuming visual media seriously in 2010ish, after the mindless watching of Disney Channel originals, I have had no problem cutting off a movie franchise or television show without receiving an ending because of the lack of investment that had initially won me over. Game of Thrones is an exception because I had to know how the writers were going to wrap up everything, although I knew going in I wasn't going to be satisfied.   Many friends and family have accused me of being crazy for this. How can I just stop watching something after spending years watching the story?   For me it has been repetitive plots from season to season. The Flash is up against another speedster, The Walking Dead has a new human antagonist to the core group while they run away from zombies, HTGAWM has another murder and utilizes the same splintered flashback storytelling. Things become stale and characters seem to learn nothing from previous seasons. With Marvel it has been the played out journey of a hero unsure if they want or should be a hero, hunting down a shiny object and doing so while some presence is threatening life on earth. I will never spend my money to see a Marvel product because they very seldom find a way to make this common storyline fresh.  Watching your videos has made me realize other reasons I have been critical of other content. Most of which boil down to lackluster writing. I more than appreciate the torture and subsequent drug abuse you endure to provide us with meaningful critique of these releases. Your a man of integrity unlike the 'professional' reviewers who suck off any major production studios poor excuse for quality film or tv.  That's all I'll say for today. I'll fuck off now

I'd say the writing was on the wall even in Ragnarok, that movie was like if you crammed two different ones together. On one hand, we have the story of the destruction of Asgard and Thor becoming king, on the other, we have a quirky comedy about Thor and Hulk trying to escape a slave planet, (don't even get me started on how they bastardized Planet Hulk,) these two stories clash with one another in a noticeable way, as we jump from tone to tone. My hate honestly increased the more I watched it. You know why everyone liked it? Because it gave them what they wanted in the worst way, they wanted Thor to be more comedic? Well here he is cracking jokes with Hulk while his home is being enslaved, you want more Guardians of the Galaxy planets, here's Sakaar but as a junkyard! You want more color? Well here's a planet painted every color of the rainbow! We basically went from a more faithful adaptation of the comics to a worse one crammed with all the shit that dragged the MCU down, all because people demanded these things.

Same exact thing happened with Wonder Woman. Great director for the first movie was then allowed to write the follow up movie. Being great at one thing doesn't make you automatically great at another. It's crazy that the movie industry is so poorly run that this type of thing happens.
The funny thing with Love and Thunder is that I genuinely want to believe that it wasn't Taika's fault. Looking across the credits for the film, I don't know what went wrong (especially since his co-writer, Jennifer Kaytin Robinson, was a fairly competent writer). Taika is a personal favourite writer because he was able to blend the childish and silly tone with the darker elements of his stories. Jojo Rabbit and Thor Ragnarok, while very goofy, still had emotional weight and depth when relevant, especially with Jojo Rabbit.  I've got a theory... but it's not one I'm particularly... happy about. I feel like something happened during the editing and writing process that, in addition to cutting down a lot of the overall screentime, also forced Taika to pad the runtime with a lot more jokes. You can feel that he wanted to do more with Gorr and several elements of the film overall, but he couldn't do it because of Marvel's "Do it quickly or not at all" mentality (which you can see in a lot of VFX and the treatment of several other films in the MCU like Multiverse of Madness, Eternals and Black Widow).

Phase 4 of the MCU has been a hot mess for the same reason the Disney Star Wars trilogy was. Lots of fancy effects but very little if any character development, world building or cohesive narrative. And the humor has become so meta that it completely takes you out of the experience and you are constantly reminded you are watching a Marvel movie rather than enjoying the story. It's great to have fan service, small references and inside jokes. But like with Dr. Strange 2 they are now bringing in characters just to instantly kill them off again. Before Endgame each movie felt like it was building on the last and giving us a satisfying Avengers movie at the end of each phase. Phase 4 feels like every show and movie is self contained and disconnected from the wider world. They are all just flashy action scenes and cheesy one liners to defeat the enemy of the week.

Oh man.... oh man does the scene you decided to say "works"... does not work. And the writing in ragnarok.... not smart. I mean sure if you compare it to love and thunder it probably is ( i wouldn't know i've stoped watching marvel) but ragnarok is garbage. Utter utter garbage.  1. Thor returns to Asgard in a middle of a crysis to find his father being out of character. Hugh. Wait: we know what Loki would do if he had power. We've already seen this in Thor 1. Now sure, you can say that he's softened up in Thor 2 - which he didn't because it's clearly established he's ruthless enough to put Odin into a coma just to stay in power -  but he still wants to be a competent leader. He's not Skar from Lion King wanting power for power's sake. His whole motivation is "Look at what i can actually DO with power". So now that he has power he's a lazy twat?  OR OR OR.... taika wiretardki just wanted Anthony Hopkins to say "oh shit".  2. The play: Having big named actors do a bad play ... IS The joke. In fact i wadged it's to make you pay less attention to the in world implications of Loki being so incompetent at a job we've seen him be quite competent as. The joke IS "Oh it's Matt Damon. Oh it's Sam Neil". That is the joke.   3. It does NOT line up with Loki's personality at all. Like at all. It lines up with a 2 year old's perspective of Loki's narcisistic personality. Sure. But to quote the movie itself "i'm a trickster'. While both THor 1, 2 and Avengers showed his hubris and narcisism, they also showed he's a ruthless competent manipulator who usually fails because he's overconfident and having an superiority complex. And while again in Thor 2, the death of his adopted mother hit him hard enough to constitue a moral shift from killing civilazations to get his way, to someone who does see value in life... he still moves the pieces in such away to take power by the end. ANd setting up a mystery as to how exactly he pulled it off.   4. Reuniting with Odin... while Anthony Hopkins kills it as Odin in his talk to Thor... where's the "You put me in a comatose body... to watch plays of yourself?!" scold to loki. IF Loki was a competent ruler under the guise of Odin, be it different, their reunion could have had a much different outcome. A much different interaction. But as such, Loki is a whiny petulent child who feels sorta bad for what he did, and in the end he helps his brother in the face of "it's this or you die" as there is no leson learned. He takes the Tessaract.   5. So as per your rules: - It does not advance the plot. It's the lightsaber throw away of the Thor Universe. Dark World promised an Unshackled Loki as ruler. We got a cop-out and a bait and switch. The plot was not advanced. It was subverted and changed. Oh sure the "New" plot where Loki is a petulent child... sure. That gets advanced i guess.  - it did not develop any character. It butchered Loki, turning him from a master manipulator, a deeply flawed character, with selfish and tragic intentions, to a sassy bitch who wanted to drink wine. The "arc" is not satisfying as there is no ark. Loki helps his brother because Hella. That's it. In that moment he saw no other way out. That's it. Taking the Tessaract proves there was no lesson learned.  - World Building. Yes. Asgard declines under Loki's 3 year old leadership. Which it shouldn't. At all. There is no worldbuilding.  - it's not funny. It's a meta joke. "look at the actors you didn't expect". That is the joke. IN world, as mentioned the implications are ... so so stupid.
Sort of like the Death of Gwen Stacy from the Amazing Spider-Man movies, I can't remember WHO made the video on that subject, (you, Nerdrotic, someone else?) but the movie people clearly just had a "surface level understanding" of that event from the old comic book. And as such, they didn't comprehend the Emotional impact of the scene & WHY it worked, and merely did a sort of copy/paste of the Event itself!  (Making it feel shallow & empty)

It's not a difficult question to answer.  It makes total sense to be tongue-in-cheek when you are explaining comic book settings, because if you try and make things like Asgard sound serious your audience is going to be very slim. However, once that's done - you still want characters that are going through emotional journeys and a story that's relatable through the emotions and connections the characters experience. When everything is a joke - you're making a comedy film, which it wasn't. Same story with second avengers film - surprising to see same mistakes made again.

Examples of movies where the directors' success made them think they didn't need a competent screen writer: Wonder Woman 1984 and Thor: Love and Thunder. Movies where the book author's movies' success made them think they didn't need a competent screen writer: The Fantastic Beast trilogy. Screen writers have never had a lot of respect in Hollywood, but it might the most important job because it's the basis for the entire movie. Yet, it seems anyone that enjoys some success thinks they can write a screen play. Some can, but many can't.

The DNA of writing good scenes involves 3 questions: 1. "Who wants what from whom?" 2. "Why do they want it now?" 3. "What happens if they don't get it?"  Every single plot point, scene, character action, and line of dialogue should, in some way, address & answer these 3 questions -- the reason being that they inherently move the plot & characters forwards. Your characters should always have a goal, and they're either pushing themselves towards it or are being pulled away from it (good pacing and character development both stem from this method of scene-writing).  The character's "want" doesn't have to be anything big or grandiose: it could be something as simple as "comfort", which they might find in another character unexpectedly (exposing some hidden depths to that other character, who may, for example have been established as mostly aloof beforehand).  Maybe the character wants a specific object, and they have to use a unique feature of your fictional world to get it -- bonus points if they have to use that thing in a creative way. Now you're incorporating world-building into scenes, and you're doing it naturally (i.e., without info dumps or lengthy exposition).

To me, Taika can be a really funny guy. However, the reason why he needs oversight is that when he's put in charge of the project, he almost leaves no room for the scenes to breathe. Is just joke after joke.  The best comedies are not written punch line after punch line, they also give us something to process, and most times can get pretty serious in the third act. Taika, at most, will be a bit serious in a small portion of the fourth act, but he'll try to move on to another joke as fast as he can from there. The first few times can be really fun, but it gets to a point where your audience is going "Ok dude, we get it. Can we get to the meat already?", and by that point is not even funny anymore because he already exhausted you. Video pitch: Why Modern Movies Suck - They Try To Be In On The Joke  One of the many unwelcome trends that I‚Äôve picked up on in movies over the past few years is how they excessively lean on the crutch of making self-referential jokes that aren‚Äôt as funny or clever as they think they are. The concept of parody only works if a) it‚Äôs the exception instead of the rule, and b) it actually subverts tropes in a clever way instead of just calling attention to it. One of my favorite examples is the superhero landing gag from Deadpool. As is, all they do is have Angel Dust do a normal superhero landing and Deadpool spoon feeds the awareness to us by making fun of it instead of letting us connect the dots ourselves. What would‚Äôve actually been funny is if they built up to it for a few seconds with a slow mo walk with cool music laid over it only for Angel Dust to jump and break her legs on impact, being immediately taken out of the fight because that‚Äôs not how we expect those moments to go. Over the past few years, it seems like more and more movies have blatant winks to the audience like this because it‚Äôs easier than writing actual intelligent jokes. In short, just acknowledging that a certain trope or clich√© exists isn‚Äôt funny on its own and it usually comes off as a bunch of out of touch producers inserting what they think people want from movies. You have to actually play on it in some way for it to work.

At this point do we even need an explanation as to why it sucked?
How the MCU deals with humor these days is a major issue. Phases 1-3 dealt with it in a way in which the humor was more of an ice breaker or a light hearted exchange between the characters that never messed with or ruined a serious plot. The story was still every bit as serious as it was needed to be. Phase 4 treats humor like its a necessity in every show or movie irrespective of what the story requires. Thor love and thunder is a film which requires a very serious approach given it's context. Instead Waititi was like "make Thor funny hehehehe"
Love and Thunder happened because Ragnarok was successful.  The studio let go of their director leash and let Waititi run wild. Not unlike what happened with Jenkins and WW84.
